title: 115_hr2831
content: The "Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act" requires the Secretary to submit updates on the strategic plan for enhancing international supply chain security every three years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the Container Security Initiative. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to update the Container Security Initiative timelines and redesignate subparagraphs. Additionally, the Cyber at Ports section is introduced. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to update the Container Security Initiative timelines and introduce cybersecurity enhancements to maritime security activities, including facilitating information sharing on cybersecurity risks and incidents and incorporating cybersecurity into vulnerability assessments and security plans. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include cybersecurity enhancements for maritime security, focusing on prevention, management, and response to cybersecurity risks and incidents. SEC. 5. Facility inspection intervals are amended to verify the effectiveness of security plans at least once a year without notice, and more frequently as needed. SEC. 6. Recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs is addressed in the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006. SEC. 218 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 addresses the recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs. The Secretary must notify congressional committees before signing an arrangement with a foreign government for mutual recognition of supply chain security practices. The foreign government's supply chain security program must provide comparable security as that provided by C-TPAT. Additionally, SEC. 7 updates the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 434 updates the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specified committees, updating the plan released in July 2011. The plan includes coordination of maritime operations, joint domain awareness efforts, information sharing with officials and the private sector on maritime security threats. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specified committees, updating the plan released in July 2011. This includes cooperation with other government agencies and local officials, coordination with the private sector on maritime security threats, and adherence to national and Department maritime security strategic guidance. SEC. 8. EVALUATION OF COAST GUARD DEPLOYABLE SPECIALIZED FORCES. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to specific committees on the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), including cost analysis, personnel numbers, unit totals, operations conducted, and operations requested. In a report on the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), the Comptroller General will assess the number of operations carried out by various entities, examine alternative distributions of DSFs, and define a DSF as a quick reaction force for deployment. The Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF) is a quick reaction force deployed for counter-drug, counter-terrorism, and anti-terrorism operations to address maritime threats to the United States. SEC. 9. COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF CO-LOCATING DHS ASSETS. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime operational assets of U.S. Customs and Border Protection's Office of Air and Marine Operations with other Department of Homeland Security agencies within 45 miles. Factors considered include enhanced cooperation, shared maintenance facilities, joint use of infrastructure, and operational costs. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets within 45 miles, considering operational costs, moving costs, and infrastructure expenses. A report summarizing the analysis results and planned actions must be submitted to relevant committees within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 10 repeals Sections 70107A and 70116 of title 46, United States Code. SEC. 11 includes conforming and clerical amendments. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections, including subsections and sections related to port security. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking sections related to port security, including sections 701, 702, 703, 704, 705, 706, 707, and 708. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new provisions such as prohibition of transportation security cards for certain felons, long-range vessel tracking, notice of arrival for foreign vessels, enhanced crewmember identification, random searches of containers, work stoppages resolution, threat assessment for port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for US Virgin Islands, and a Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new provisions related to supply chain security cooperation, trucking security, air and marine operations, vessel phaseout, Coast Guard property, methamphetamine control, and disaster safety. Amendments also involve changes in title 46 regarding vessel tracking and crew identification.
